title: Strictly sisters Oti and Motsi Mabuse up against each other at NTAs
text:
Oti and Motsi Mabuse have both been long-listed for an NTA (Picture: Getty)

Strictly Come Dancing’s Oti and Motsi Mabuse are going head-to-head at the upcoming National Television Awards in 2020.

The sisters, who are both currently starring on the current series of the BBC show, have been named as contenders in the Best TV Judge category for their roles on The Greatest Dancer and Strictly.

Bruno Tonioli and Shirley Ballas have also been shortlisted for the accolade, as has X Factor’s Simon Cowell, All Together Now’s Geri Horner and The Great British Bake Off’s Paul Hollywood.

There are 36 nominees in total and fans will be able to vote for their favourite.

The candidates will then be whittled down once more and the public will then be asked to select their winner later in the year.

Motsi is a new judge on Strictly (Picture: PA)

Motsi replaced Dame Darcey Bussell on Strictly this year, where her sister Oti is a professional dancer.

Talking of working alongside her sibling, the 38-year-old said: ‘I’m not nervous about working with Oti because we’ve done it before.

‘I’ve been teaching her since she could walk, and we have a big sense of trust as sisters.’

She continued to Good Housekeeping: ‘We’re professional at what we do and we want to get that professionalism across..we want to go into this with fresh energy and have fun.’

Last month, it had been revealed that newest addition Motsi had become the target of a racial hate group that had caused the show to increase their security according to reports.

‘Strictly rightly take the safety of their stars very seriously, and felt that the move was warranted. And they would rather be over than under cautious,’ a source told The Sun.

Meanwhile, a Strictly rep told Metro.co.uk: ‘We have extensive security measures in place to protect cast, crew and audience, and arrangements are reviewed on a regular basis.’

Strictly Come Dancing continues on Saturday at 6.40pm on BBC One.
